Award.AwardTitle: Ultra-efficient Power Delivery Architecture and Topologies for IT Systems (UPDATE-IT)

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: Data centers, the backbone of today's information era, are expected to consume ~73 billion kWh in 2020, which amounts to ~$7.3 billion in electricity cost in the U.S. alone. This is one of the fastest growing loads on the electric grid in the U.S. as well as worldwide, because of customers' soaring demands for online data and cloud computing. This rapid-increasing consumption significantly contributes to global carbon emissions. Therefore, updating the power delivery for data centers with improved efficiency is an important societal need. The goal of this project is to address this power consumption bottleneck by using a new power distribution and conversion architecture that is compact, scalable, ultra-efficient, low-heat, low-cost, and reliable. If successful, a wide application of the proposed system could result in more than 8.1 billion kWh or ~$810 million annual savings in electricity consumption for data centers in the U.S. alone. These savings would, in turn, reduce harmful greenhouse gas emission of ~1.3 million passenger cars from U.S. roads. The impact can be further amplified by adoptions of the proposed system and its sub-systems in other information technology applications, such as communication systems, automotive, high-performance portable devices, etc. The research will be conducted by graduate students and undergraduate students who will be equipped with the knowledge and skills in integrated power electronics and energy efficiency for future opportunities in both professional and educational development. The research will also involve educational efforts including official curriculum offerings and outreach activities to K-12 students.<br/><br/>To achieve the research goal, the team will explore a radically different power distribution and management architecture for future green data centers and other information technology systems. Employing new converter topologies that can efficiently support large conversion ratios, the architecture reduces the number of power conversion stages from the grid to core voltages from four or more to only two. The first stage, converting grid AC voltage to a DC bus voltage, electrically stack server boards in close proximity in a server rack to allow each of them to handle only a fraction of the input grid AC voltage, leading to ultra-high power conversion efficiency, low cost and high reliability. This first conversion stage also exploits a novel, experimentally validated smart-cable method that can significantly reduce on-board heat, leading to substantial thermal management cost reductions. For the second stage converting the DC bus to core voltages, the research team will explore a new direct-conversion hybrid DC-DC converter topology family to enable superior efficiency and power density at extremely large conversion ratios. The research plan includes design, fabrication, and verification of multiple new hybrid converter topologies, integrating different types of AC-DC and DC-DC hybrid converters, smart-cable solution design and implementation, system failure protection circuit implementation and test, system scaling for different specifications and applications, and benchmarking against existing solutions.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data centers, the backbone of today's information era, consume ~73 billion kWh in 2020, which amounts to ~$7.3 billion in electricity cost in the U.S. alone. This is one of the fastest growing loads on the electric grid in the U.S. as well as worldwide, because of customers' soaring demands for online data and cloud computing. This rapid-increasing consumption significantly contributes to global carbon emissions. Therefore, updating the power delivery for data centers with improved efficiency is an important societal need. The goals of this project are set to address this power consumption bottleneck by using a new power distribution and conversion architecture that is compact, scalable, ultra-efficient, low-heat, low-cost, and reliable, and to train the next generation engineers relevant specific skillsets and exposure to this important area of engineering.

To achieve the research goal, in the 4 years of the project the team has explored a radically different power distribution and management architecture for future green data centers and other information technology systems. Employing new converter topologies that can efficiently support large conversion ratios, the architecture showed possible efficient reduction of the number of power conversion stages from the grid to core voltages from four or more to only two. The first stage, converting grid AC voltage to a DC bus voltage, electrically stacks server boards in close proximity in a server rack to allow each of them to handle only a fraction of the input grid AC voltage, leading to ultra-high power conversion efficiency, low cost and high reliability. This first conversion stage also exploits a novel architecture that achieves 96% efficiency for 200VAC-to-48VDC promising substantial thermal management cost reductions. For the second stage converting the DC bus (48V) to core voltages (~1V), the research team investigated and demonstrated a new direct-conversion hybrid DC-DC converter topology family, called the multi-inductor hybrid (MIH) converter family to enable superior efficiency (91%-95%), power density (2.2 kW/in3, or ~1 kA/in3), and extremely large conversion ratios (48V-to-1V). The research work were comprehensive, including design, fabrication, and verification of multiple new hybrid converter topologies, integrating different types of AC-DC and DC-DC hybrid converters, circuit implementation and test, system scaling for different specifications and applications, and benchmarking against existing solutions.

For dissemination of the research program, the research team has published a total of 9 peer-reviewed conference papers at the top two conferences of the fields, including the IEEE Applied Power Electronics Conference and Exposition (APEC) and the IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition (ECCE); 4 peer-reviewed journal papers at the IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications (TIA), the IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics (JESTPE), and the IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics (TIE); 1 lecture at ISSCC attended by 87 people; 1 PELS-SSCS webinar that was attended by 644 people; and 1 college webinar attended by >70 college students and teachers. The PI of the research also leads the power engineering track at UC San Diego and helps growing the power electronics class students by ~20%/year in the last 3 years that he joined the university. 

As one key important mission of creating impact in education and training, the research has attracted 4 Ph.D. students, 3 M.S. students, and 7 undergraduate students to join the group. The students are given opportunities to participate in professional development activities that result in increased knowledge and skills in power electronics. Particularly, they are provided opportunities to be trained to write good papers, submit papers, go to top-tier conferences, and interact with other professionals and industry companies. 1 Ph.D. student has graduated and earned a Ph.D. degree from the work of this project. An undergraduate student's research in Remote Area Power Supply System using Solar Energy was accepted and presented at the 2020 ECCE student project demo. This was a significant achievement for a female undergraduate student who experienced power electronics hardware and development for the first time. 6 other undergraduate students joined a power electronics research group and tried to work on hands-on power electronics hardware (PCB implementations) for the first time. These activities overall have provided an excellent experience for the students, not only to improve their professional and personal skills, but also to maintain and boost their interests, courage, and determination to pursue this important area of study and research. Two undergraduate students continued to their M.S. degree in the same group in power electronics. One undergraduate student goes on to work for SpaceX on power delivery for space mission. One graduated Ph.D. student is applying to become a future professor/principal investigator in power electronics.
